Children and teens are now spending more: Children and teens are now spending more time online. Being connected helps them reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages them to continue with their lives..but it also presents risks and dangers.
Adults targeting children for sexual pur: Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming and messaging platforms.
Harmful content-violence, misogyny, xeno: Harmful content-violence, misogyny, xenophobia, inciting suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography etc.
Teens sharing personal information and s: Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
Tech fixes to protect your children onli: Tech fixes to protect your children online
Cover webcams when not in use.
Create healthy and safe online habits: Create healthy and safe online habits
in creating family tech agreements about: in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
Create device free spaces and times in y: Create device free spaces and times in your house(eating, playing, schoolwork and sleeping).
Help your child learn how to keep person: Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers-some people are not who they say they are.
Remind your children that what goes onli: Remind your children that what goes online stays online(messages, photos and videos).
Actively supervise children's time onlin: Actively supervise children's time online, including computers, smartphones and tablets.
Spend time with your child or teen onlin: Spend time with your child or teen online
Explore websites, social media, games an: Explore websites, social media, games and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report inapp: Talk to your teen on how to report inappropriate content(see below).
Keep your child safe with open communica: Keep your child safe with open communication
Tell your children that if they experien: Tell your children that if they experience sometihng online that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.
Be alert to signs of distress. Notice if: Be alert to signs of distress. Notice if your child is being withdrawn, upset, secretive, or obsessed with online activities.
Create trusting relationships and open c: Create trusting relationships and open communication through positive support and encouragement.
Note that every child is unique and may: Note that every child is unique and may use different ways to communicate. Take time to adjust your message for your child's needs. For example, children with learning disabilities, may require information in simple format.
